title: 114_hr2274
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Congress finds that the 850,000 first responders of Emergency Medical Services answer over 30,000,000 calls annually to assist 22,000,000 patients in need of immediate care, showcasing selfless dedication and American spirit. This commitment also plays a crucial role in the Nation's homeland defense strategy. Emergency Medical Services, along with Law Enforcement and the Fire Service, are vital in preventing and mitigating risks from various incidents. They play a critical role in national security efforts and ensuring domestic tranquility. Unfortunately, these responders face a high rate of injury and fatality in their line of duty. Emergency Medical Services providers have a high injury and fatality rate, more than twice the national average for all occupational fatalities. They make selfless sacrifices to maintain domestic tranquility and serve the nation and its citizens. Their responsibilities are broad and unique. The Emergency Medical Services providers make selfless sacrifices with a high injury and fatality rate, deserving recognition for their commitment to serving the nation. Authorization to establish a commemorative work. The National Emergency Medical Services Memorial Foundation may establish a commemorative work in the District of Columbia to honor emergency medical services. The establishment must comply with the Commemorative Works Act and cannot use federal funds for expenses. The Foundation is responsible for all costs. The National Emergency Medical Services Memorial Foundation is solely responsible for accepting contributions and paying for the establishment of a commemorative work in the District of Columbia. Any excess funds after all expenses are paid will be deposited with the Secretary of the Interior. The National Emergency Medical Services Memorial Foundation is responsible for accepting contributions and paying for a commemorative work in the District of Columbia. Any excess funds will be transferred to a separate account with the National Park Foundation for memorials, available to the Secretary of the Interior or Administrator as per the process in the United States Code.
